content.description: Same as Time of the Profits, but do not use the boulder at the start. That one little change makes all the difference.
content.location: Center of the Outer North Face, just to the left of the large tree.

content.description: This climb follows a series of flakes. Start where the small boulder (V1) sticks up out of the ground directly below a left facing flake. Using the boulder makes the first crux easier. Avoid it if you want to keep a stiffer challenge. Small crimpers, slopers and an undercling will get you to the flake. Power up to the top of the first flake and head to the right aiming for a small right facing flake on good but very sharp/small crimpers (crux). Once you make it to the right facing flake, work your way up and to the left to another left facing flake at the top.
content.location: On the Outer North Wall, just to the left of the large oak tree. A few feet right of "The Historian".

content.description:
Start 7' from the right edge of the rock. Climb up past a small right-facing corner (crux; V1, see "Dawn Of Mankind") to a ledge. Follow the ledge with your hands (taking care not to dislodge the small rock) left and up, working your feet on what seems like a blank wall, heading for the large right-facing flake/corner. Once in the corner; layback, jam, work the face or stem your way to the top. Rated X because the bottom half is unprotected. 

  At the top you can see the old remains of webbing from climbers long ago.
content.protection: Best to TR. But for the trad guys/gals, medium gear will work.
content.location: South inner face, left side (near tunnel through the boulders).

content.description: Start below the prominent detached left-facing flake. Climb straight up through an incipient crack until you can reach the top.
content.location: Located on the left end of the outer north-facing wall.

content.description: Instead of making the 5.9 move off the ground, move to the far right and work up the edge of the arÃªte till you get to a small upward facing flake, on small holds work the small flake over to the left until you met up with "The Remains of Mankind".

This outcrop of rock probably has the most potential of the three areas here. There are perhaps a dozen lines on this rock. There are several boulders immediately around and behind it that offer their own problems and challenges. The main rock itself is composed of two parallel 'fins' of rock, stacked against a cluster of large boulders between them. The main walls of the two fins face north and south. *Only reasonable Top Rope anchors would be trees about 30ft south of each top out (and down the back of the fin)*
